Hi friends.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
I appreciate you letting me take some time away from this space. I can’t say I’m completely ready to jump back in but I can feel the gravitational pull to dip my feet back in the water I adore so much.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
The last few months I have been settling into a new job. After quitting my job in healthcare last March and attempting to make this account my full-time career to then deciding my soul didn’t want that either 🤷🏼‍♀️ to now being back to working full-time again...my brain needed quiet. I needed to simplify my outgoing current. It’s been such a whirlwind of a year and I’m learning that it’s okay to step back from some things in order to steady the ground beneath me. There were many times I came to this account but my thoughts went blank. I had nothing to say. Nothing to share. My creativity switch turned to power-saving mode and sometimes it frustrated me but I also understood. It’s okay for me to lean away from some things so I can better lean into others. A lot of my heart and energy pours into this space and I needed all the heart and energy I could muster to get me through this new transition. It’s easy for some people to start something new and still juggle the other moving parts in their life but not for me. Something always has to give, even if it’s just for a little awhile. So thank you for letting me do that.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
From a mental health standpoint, I’m doing well. I’m seeing my OCD specialist two times a month and continuing to see improvements in areas I never thought I would. There are still hard moments. There are still days when my brain plays tricks on me and my thoughts try to change the truthful narrative. But there are more good days now. So many more. This time last year I sat in my car thinking about ending my life because my OCD was so unmanageable. Here I am a year later lying in the grass outside the local farmers market, munching on some fresh cherries, writing for the first time in months, less than a week away from my 29th birthday, having the most amazing time planning our wedding and in good mental health. I am so thankful for all of that & I’m thankful for all of you.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Catch me up. How are you?💚

***EDIT- This giveaway is now over! Thank you for participating!*** This #MentalHealthAwarenessMonth I’m excited to announce I’ve once again partnered with the hearts behind @myintent for a another MINDFUL GIVEAWAY!  @myintent is an amazing company focused on starting meaningful conversations beginning with your own customized pieces. The importance of conversation when it comes to mental health is so crucial and this is such a beautiful way to spark one.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
I chose the number 9. Because on my hardest days, the I-can’t-help-but-believe-my-thoughts-even-though-I-know-it’s-my-OCD-making-something-out-of-nothing-days, or the painful and empty days- I want to remember my favorite month with my favorite person. I want to remember the love, the support, and the blanket of happiness that wraps itself around me whenever I think of the month of September- our dating month, our engagement month and our future wedding month. When I look down I remember the journey I’m never walking alone and how grateful I am for this amazing man who loves even the darkest parts of me. That is why I chose 9.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
For the next 48 hours I will be leaving this post open for you to share what your word would be and why you chose it. 5 lucky followers will be chosen to receive their own personalized discount code good for one twist bracelet! I am so excited to see what you all share here. Let’s start the conversation now✨
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀

This time last year I quit my full-time career to take the biggest risk of my life. By March 2018 I had been managing this account for 6 years. I never made a penny from it before then. People would say “Wow you could be making so much money! Why don’t you do sponsored content?! I know this person and they made thousands off of just one post!” Honestly, those suggestions always frustrated me. I wasn’t in it for that. I created this community from the ground up because it’s what I needed during the loneliest season of my life. There’s no dollar amount that could have given me the comfort and support like I’ve found here. I didn’t want to capitalize off this safe place and be another person trying to market the latest fit tea or hair gummy in exchange for a check. I wouldn’t do it.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
I was working in healthcare at that time. I loved the work I did but I hated the cost of doing it. I was barely making ends meet, had a growing credit card bill, immersed in toxic management and I was so fucking tired. Careful deliberation mixed with pure exhaustion and I made the decision that if I was going to make this account my career it had to be done my way. I had to create my own box for me to fit into. Mindful partnerships. Relevant sponsored ads. Complete and total transparency. It took hours of therapy for me to reframe my mindset and accept that I was worthy of financially supporting myself while also doing what I love. I’ve never had both before. It’s always been one or the other and the idea that I could possibly live a comfortable life while loving what I did seemed like a path worth exploring. So I quit. I took the biggest risk of my life and I quit to pursue that full-time influencer life but on my terms.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
And guess what?
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
I couldn’t do it.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
I’m just not built for it.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
My storytelling doesn’t work this way.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
More to come on why I’m going back to work. More to come on why it’s okay to admit “I CAN’T DO SOMETHING BECAUSE I’M HUMAN AND I CAN’T DO SOME SHIT!” So this risk didn’t make for a great success story in the end. Ah well. What matters is that I learned and maybe that’s the ending I was always meant for.
Oh my. @risingwoman

Let’s talk fear of panic attacks in public or for some of you panic attacks TRIGGERED by public. 
I personally struggled with both in the past. 
I always had a fear of “embarrassing” myself by having a panic attack in public. I could even visualize it and of course my visualizations were always 100 times more dramatic than the situation would/could ever be. I imagined not being able to control myself, freaking out, and an ambulance having to take me to the doctor... needless to say as much as I feared this, it never happened. That’s my biggest point today- almost all of our fears, biggest worries never come true or even close to true but we spend so much time thinking about them, playing them out like they exist and almost acting like it already happened sometimes. Comment 🙋🏼‍♀️ if you can relate to that one. 
Then there is panic triggered by public. If you are anything like me you have created a correlation (That isn’t true but youve convinced yourself it is) that going in public or to certain places will automatically cause a panic attack. I know I am very guilty of this. I let it get to the point of everywhere I had had a panic attack or felt my heart racing before I cut off ever going back to... which led to agoraphobia. I made a connection in my brain that being home was only safe. I wish someone would’ve looked at me back then and said walk back into that store and don’t leave- show yourself and your mind that that store isn’t dangerous and the panic attack wasn’t caused by the store it was caused by the fear and anxious thoughts I had leading up to the store. That’s when I started exposure therapy with myself- showing my mind that the places I “feared” going to due to having a past panic attack weren’t dangerous but I related them to the panic attack and labeled them as dangerous. Showing myself and my mind that I can go there and be okay helped lessen the fear, which helped lessen the thoughts. If we constantly go into a situation with the mindset “this makes me anxious, i am worried about having a panic attack there because this this and this” then we are ultimately setting ourselves up to panic. Next time, try to think ... continue in comments below

“I am” two of the most powerful words known. I don’t care if you don’t feel it, claim it. It’s easy to say “I am depressed I am anxious” but we are subconsciously setting the tone for our mental state. You have the power. You set the tone to what you want to be today. “Today, I am brave and any anxiety that comes my way might be irritating but that’s okay because I am brave and it will pass”
I used to think it was dumb to claim stuff like that... until I read the science behind it. Why we might think it’s dumb but when you continually claim things you start to believe them..then you start to feel them. This is true science.
I’m guilty of in the past being the ultimate negative Nancy 🙋🏼‍♀️🙋🏼‍♀️
Things I used to say “I am not smart enough” “I am too anxious””I am depressed” “ I am not enough” “I am not okay” and feeding my brain that over & over took a toll.
Even when I don’t feel okay, I remind myself I am okay. 
Even when I don’t feel like I’m enough, I remind myself I am enough & capable of all things.
You are too.
So today, what are you? 
Comment below what you are.

Intrusive thoughts by definition are unwanted thoughts or images that you find distressing. These unwanted thoughts are known as obsessions. What gives these thoughts power is when people who experience them become worried about the significance of the thoughts. Reminder: thoughts are just thoughts, they are not real nor harmful. 
Some examples of intrusive thoughts:
1. “I always feel like everyone is looking at me and laughing. If someone is laughing it has to be at me. If people are taking it’s about me”
2. “I truly feel something terrible is about to happen any second” and then possibly seeing the scenario in your head of what you are worried about. 
3. “I don’t really love my significant other” When they are the most important person in your life.
4. “My children would be better off with a better mom. My husband only stays with me because I’m free day care. No on loves me.” These are just some.. then there are other deeper intrusive thoughts that you may be dealing with- thoughts of doing something impulsive. *TRIGGER WARNING*
In the past during my panic disorder I had the same intrusive thought come to my mind a few times while driving, it was when I was driving over a bridge “what if I just drove off the ledge” It wasn’t an action thought but it was the most random thought that would appear and scare me. Back then before I knew how to cope with thoughts, I feared the thought was bigger than me and would cause me to do that. But the truth is thoughts are just thoughts and WE have the power. 
If you experience intrusive thoughts, trust me I know its scary. I remember when I would get those thoughts I would feel “bad” for thinking that. But what I did to help was remind myself that it was just a thought, a thought cannot hurt me, a thought is an imagination not a real action. I have the power to not act on my thoughts. 
Continually going through the process in your mind when you get the these unwanted thoughts. 
Steps to take to deal with intrusive thoughts: 
1. Label your intrusive thoughts as “just thoughts” Remind yourself they have no power.
2. Remind yourself that you have the power and you can safely avoid them
3. Accept ... continued in comments👇🏼

They say a picture is worth a 1,000 words, I’d say this picture is worth a million.
I have yet to give credit to the ones who stuck by my side even when I didn’t want to stick by my side. 
In this picture is my dog Bentley (on the left)- I got him right when my anxiety was getting really bad. He was the biggest blessing I could ever ask for and still is. 
Then there is my boyfriend and patches (his dog) - they were there for me before extreme anxiety, during extreme anxiety, and still here.
I am forever thankful for all of them for sticking through the worst days. I won’t say it was always perfect though, there were times he (and if the dogs could speak, they😂) got frustrated, annoyed, needed space from my panic attacks, constant worries/googling symptoms, was sick of going to the doctor with me... but looking back when I was in the darkest, I didn’t even understand myself. Something I’ve learned through this journey is Grace- giving grace when others don’t understand your battles, giving grace when others get a little frustrated at time and allowing them space because switch the roles in your mind.. would you have always been patient? We are all human. Giving grace is beautiful.
Along with this picture is my other favorite things- everything I used to help & healing and created into @anxietytoolkit it was such an amazing project for me to put together for no one to ever feel alone & to have a safe place! 
Last but not least, my favorite nights are spent with making a movie watching pallet on the amazing @lullbed with alll the fall smells! Fall is my favorite time of year. 
This picture is my favorite picture forever.

Adding on to my last post.... my story, my journey continues. 
@wegohealth has blessed me with winning Best In Show Instagram. 😭💚 I I owe so much of it to all of you who voted and then all of the wego health judges who chose me. I remember when I was at my worst saying God if there is a way I ever make it out of this I promise to use this and do good. I remember when I started to slowly get less and less panic attacks I said alright I promised. I got on Instagram and made this safe place- at first it was just few of you guys and I. I thought it was so cool even when it was just that, now I get to share my story with 100,000 of you amazing people fighting everyday with me. 
From always feeling like I was never enough always trying to find my place and where I fit in, I ALWAYS fit in with mental health and so do you. Mental health advocacy is where I am meant to be. It’s my passion. 
If I never went through what I went though, if I never drowned under the waves I would have never found my purpose. To help others for the rest of my life in any way I can going through what I went through and RISING UP.
I know the waves are rough, I know you’re fighting warrior let me tell you DO NOT LOSE HOPE. You will get through this and do something amazing.
Grow through what you go through. 
I hope I can be apart of helping you all grow forever and watching the amazing things you guys will do too.

THIS TOO SHALL PASS.
Keep fighting warrior. 
Hold on to the hope that if I can get through it, so can you. You are just as brave and as strong as me.

Alot of my clients ask how do they stop the negative thoughts they are getting, the key to breaking the negative cycle of thinking and anxiety is to Change your relationship with your thoughts. Allow the thoughts to come and almost be a bystander and question the validity of the thoughts you are thinking. Thoughts are not facts they are random messed up information and are well known for being aload of BS. By changing the way you react to your thoughts you are teaching your brain that there is an alternative way of thinking and instead of seeing the negative thoughts as a threat or danger your brain will dismiss the thoughts almost immediately.
-
-Journalling is a great way to start to put this into practice next time you recognise a negative thought write it down and next to it write down an alternative positive thought. This is giving your brain the alternative outlook practice practice practice until it becomes second nature and you are not having to write the thoughts down you will get to the stage where you are doing it subconsciously. 💕💕💕

🎨@daylightpotato 🥔😊
.
📈ANXIETY
A natural human response to STRESS in the mind or body. Perceived or real DANGER.
Such as
An existing illness, WORRYING you & putting STRAIN on your body. 
Too much WORRY in your life
HOLDING in intense EMOTION, swallowing it. 
HORMONE imbalance
NO sleep
NO support 
Loneliness, sadness.
Not enough NUTRITIONAL value in your diet
A LACK of magnesium
PAIN from the past that hasn't gone anywhere.
A CLOSED MINDSET
FEAR of something 
Etc.
.
📈What happens is we experience anxiety because of a cause such as 1 or many of the above, & without knowledge of anxiety, & not knowing about the real causes, we become fearful of anxiety. Then we beat ourselves up for experiencing it, assume it's down to us as a human that were some how broken. The worry continues, causing more anxiety.
.
💡It's not as you imagine.
Experiencing anxiety can be helped, be brought down, you can feel better again. So that the next time you experience anxiety from one of the above causes *life* *anxiety is normal for the circumstances* you will know how to manage it, you won't feel afraid & you'll know how to bring it down= less worry, passes sooner. Then 👇
Address the causes.
.
BUT
.
❤The 1st move is to take care of your Heart
No more blaming yourself
Accepting you're feeling anxious 
It WILL pass
But you Have to take care
You cannot expect anxiety to reduce doing  all the same things as before. The things that caused anxiety.
.
📉A better sleep routine 
Ask for support
A nutritional diet 
Cancel plans
Breathe
Don't plan too much
Productivity 👎not important, your health & wellbeing is.
Have some nights in
Put down social media
Do something you enjoy
Get outside 🌳🕊
Speak to a doctor
Know that you deserve to feel good even if you're not used to putting you first, it's time you did. Waiting for that person to do it, will probubly never happen. You do it for you. Put your arms around yourself, make a promise to yourself that you are strong enough to love you like you should be loved.
.
Take care x
.
#anxiety

BUT not before I'd seen the cbt therapist i visited when I was experiencing fear of going out, fear of sleeping, fear or eating, fear fear fear which turned out to be fear of panic happening anywhere.
.
🗣She asked me how are you? It was the first time I felt that I could REALLY answer that question honestly. .
No-one was going to get upset with my words. 
No-one would find out how I really felt.
No-one had ever really truely wanted to know, really!
I had never felt that I could have a connection like that with anyone.
.
Boy did I cry, i cried for the whole hour, 'someone is asking me for real how am I?'
It was an hour well spent, the best I ever had because I connected with someone.
.
The connection had been missing.
TRUSTING someone, to just listen, let me be honest without making what I said about them. Trusting someone would want to listen, that I was safe to say.
.
That was my true healing, what I needed the most.
The rest came from knowledge of anxiety & trusting that they wanted to help me. Talking helped me to unravel all that was going on in my mind, from one ball of mess which was fear of anxiety, fear of emotion, pain from the past, not looking after myself, my needs, my heart. Coping mechanisms that didnt serve me well now, family patterns i had learnt. Plus all the problems that were in my life then. All together, with no trust & no help was unorganized & unmanageable 😓
.
So if you are thinking about therapy or you have connected to my story.
You deserve that feeling you can trust someone, it's what you should have. If you haven't had it, just like me you can look for it until you find it, from the doctor, from a therapist, from a coach.
.
You don't have to wait for them to change, you can make a change.
.
#anxiety #trust

X out the need for more | WE DON'T need MORE | The drive for more keeps your adrenaline on 📈 .
.
✒@anxiety_wellbeing
🎨@marimaribooboo 🌱
.
MORE 
You've done your work but still feel that its not enough, you must give more.

You've earned enough for what you NEED but in your thoughts it's not enough.
.
You're always spending, then next thing comes up that you want, the 😊 didn't last long. What's next?
.
You feel you must own more, what you have isn't enough.
.
I should be feeling more, happy, I'm always questioning 'am I happy enough?'
.
🤔That's just an idea/belief we've been feed to keep the commercial world earning 💰you think you NEED it. You've done your best but still, it doesn't feel enough. .
WHY?
.
Do you know about the ABC model? Ellis.
.
Actionable event 
Beliefs 
Concequenses.
.
Most people think that cognitively 
we go A-C👇
Event- it makes us feel a certain way so we - act. 👇
You pass someone in the street, they appear to ignore you(A)- you feel angry or upset so you decide to ignore them next time. (C)
.
But. Really it's A-B-C example👇
.
You pass someone in the street, they appear to ignore you(A)- you feel angry or upset (subconcious memory) you believe that they must be ignoring you because this isn't the first time someone has appeard to ignore you (B) so you decide to ignore them next time.(C)
.
So how does that come into play in this scenario of MORE? 
If we have been feed ideas that we never have enough & this idea is a pretty lucrative one if you are selling a product that you want people to want. So how do you do it?
.
Advertise it like you need it!!
.
It's psychology, & the commercial world has been telling you you need IT since adverts began.
.
It's now part of our subconcious So.
.
You work (A) you feel tired & in need of a break but you believe it's not enough, we have to keep striving for more(B)you keep going even though it's not good for you(C)
.
Hello Anxiety.
.
🌱Notice what your beliefs are saying to you subconsciously
Where does it come from?
Is it helpful? 
Change your belief=change the action
.
A-ANXIOUS
B-belief it's caused by something in your life & you can do something about it.
C-look for causes & act.
.
#anxiety

A complete mix of emotions vs a straight line, you wouldn't feel anything.
.
✒@anxiety_wellbeing
🎨@thepsychologymum 🌱
.
🌱Anxiety 
It's one of the emotions that is very tough to deal with, mainly because if you become afraid of how you feel *normal* then it becomes something you try to avoid, block, run from & that, makes you feel worse.
.
🌱*Its normal that when you first experience high anxiety, panic attacks, or sometimes even suspect that you're anxious, that you will start to worry. & that's because.
.
1. Many of the symptoms feel like there IS something else badly wrong.
2. When we experience panic, this alone is very scary so fear & anxiety go hand in hand.
3. In stress response the brain naturally scans for danger, so if you feel & feel the fear it's normal.
4. If you have no knowledge, this can lead to assuming the worst. =more anxiety
5. We are talking about mental health so much, when you do feel down, now we are focused inward thinking 'is there something wrong with me have I got it?'.
.
🌱As much as emotions are tough to deal with they are tougher if you question their existence & become afraid of them.
.
🌱When we do this we block, avoid the real emotion that actually should be experienced & allowed to flow through you in its own way.
.
🌱Emotion doesn't go if you swallow, block or avoid, they stay with you, build up, come out in other ways. In behaviour, I'm health. Sometimes with anxiety.
.
🌱It can feel incredibly uncomfortable to feel an emotion but it's not hear to hurt you, you have reason to feel the way you feel, of you allow yourself to feel it, it will pass, you will feel better, it may take time but it will pass.
.
🌱No feelings, no emotions, what would that mean?
If you're never been heart broken you never LOVED
If you're you're never sad, you won't APPRECIATE GLADNESS.
If you're never anxious, you're survival mechanism isn't serving you well.
If you're never anything, you're feeling numb.
.
🌱Emotions are here to help us navigate our world's, feel all the feels, let them out, enjoy humaness. 😍
.

Note to self 🤔 Double tap if you love this as much as I do! ❤️❤️ This is part of what I teach in the Anxiety Reset Method - we consider your thoughts and beliefs, as well as your gut health, hormones, nutrition, genes and lifestyle. DM me to find out more 📧. Thank you @archhades

IS COFFEE GOOD OR BAD FOR YOU? // At last I have the answer! Is coffee good or bad for you? ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Well...
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
It depends.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
For some people, coffee doesn’t have a huge stimulating effect. Some people can sleep after a cup of coffee post-dinner (who are these people?!! 🙈) It has some benefits too - like protecting the liver.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
For others - MOST OF YOU WHO FOLLOW - it is simply anxiety fuel that you don’t need. It’s pumping stress hormones like adrenaline and cortisol into your already stressed out, over-stimulated nervous system. ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Try a week or two off it. See if you notice an improvement in your anxiety and sleep. Take the Calm In 5 Days email challenge while you’re at it, for bonus support!! Link in bio❤️

MEDITATION - WHY YOU’RE NOT DOING IT PART ONE // It’s not always an easy gig getting my clients to meditate regularly. 
I work with a lot of people with anxiety. Understanding anxiety is the first step in managing it. In knowing its erratic nature, we can obtain a better sense of triggering situations and how our anxiety operates. That’s where meditation comes in. 
Whether you frequently experience that butterflies in the stomach, sweaty palms, heart palpitations, upset stomach, or tightness in the chest feeling of adrenaline pumping or not, we know there are a myriad of benefits to meditation.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
So what is stopping you from meditating?
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
There is one reason that comes up time and time again, in my client sessions and across the world.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
I DON’T HAVE TIME TO MEDITATE.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Is this you? Do you think this too? ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
The problem here is that we all assume meditation has to be done in a 10, 20, 30 or 60 minute format, with certain rules. We are making it too hard for ourselves. Staying in meditation for less than 10 minutes and you’ve failed. There are no rules. 5 minutes is enough. Even 1 minute is enough! The person who watches their mind and breath for 1 minute a day is still receiving benefits over the person who never watches their mind. ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Personally, I usually meditate for 5-10 minutes here and there and it’s become a really regular part of my life. I can fit it in anywhere, just before bed, after a walk or session at the gym.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
If you struggle to meditate regularly, see what happens when you take the rules away.
If you would like to work further on your anxiety, I’d love to work with you. Send me a DM and let’s talk! ❤️

GUT TROUBLES? EAT THIS 👆🏻// Anxiety and an uncomfortable digestive system often go hand in hand. Have you noticed this yourself? ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
It can make the gut spasm into diarrhoea, or stop moving completely, so we get constipation 💩 ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Many people also experience bloating, gastric acid reflux and simply just feel discomfort when digesting food! All because of high stress levels and anxiety, and how our brain and gut are connected.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
For more comfortable digestion, try adding more papaya to your diet 🌸 This is one of my go-to suggestions for my clients!
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Papaya contains natural digestive enzymes that take the pressure off your body, so you can break down your food better (and more easily absorb nutrients). ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀

The song playing in the background of my mind with this quote is ‪Pat Benatar‬’s “Hit Me With Your Best Shot”. 😊This mindset of “bring it on” encompasses all the messy experiences of fear, power, bravery, discomfort, anxiety, and courage.
.
.
When we find ourself standing at that proverbial fork in the road, we find ourselves with (at times) pretty tough decisions to make. In that moment, how do we engage with our experience? How do we engage with our uncertainty? How do we engage with our anxiety? One option we have is to avoid. To escape that moment of discomfort. To run from fear. To let fear choose our path for us. When this isn’t in line with our values, what do we do?
.
.
Another option is this life motto: “hey anxiety, bring it on”. I say this to myself anytime I feel that tug of fear within myself urging me to flee. I use this as a gentle and compassionate reminder that I can allow fear to be a part of my experience without needing to do something about it.
.
.
"Yes, anxiety. Yes, fear. If you want to join me in this experience then you are welcome, but you do not get a drivers seat position. You can watch me live my life according to my values and not your own. I got this.”
.
.
Reminder: You can do hard things. You can do brave things. I believe in you SO much. You got this!
.
.

We may think that just one more compulsion, just one more ritual, will be enough to satisfy OCD. OCD will then be satiated and leave us alone. The frustrating reality is that no amount of rituals will satisfy that doubt, that discomfort, that uncertainty. It may feel like it’s better momentarily, but because of the way a ritual negatively reinforces intrusive thoughts and the resulting anxiety, the cycle will happen again. The rituals are food for those experiences to get stronger and keep coming back.
.
An example of a negative reinforcement cycle: I have a headache. I feel pain and I do not want to be in pain. I then take headache medicine with the goal of getting rid of the pain. As a result of taking the medicine, the headache goes away. The behavior of taking the medicine was reinforced by the diminishment of my pain. What happens next time? I’m now more likely to have that thought of “oh I should take medicine!” the next time I have a headache and then follow through with my behavior of taking the medication.
.
Rituals function the same way. We perform them with the intention of getting rid of our anxiety/doubt/discomfort/fear. It may “work” momentarily but because of this temporary relief, that intrusion is now being reinforced as a dangerous thing that we need to ritualize around.
.
This is why ERP is so difficult. We have to sit with our anxiety and really invite it to be a part of our experience without engaging in rituals intended to take that discomfort away. Over time and consistency, that reinforcement cycle breaks apart and we can learn new things about the experience of an intrusion (thoughts are just thoughts) and anxiety (anxiety is unpleasant but not dangerous) and uncertainty (it is a part of the human experience and can be embraced). This can be so hard but it is so worth it! You are worth it!
.
I believe in your ability to do hard things! I believe in YOU! You got this💛
.

Have you ever struggled with the notion that feeling afraid must mean that you are not a strong individual? That the experience of fear removes any opportunity for strength? I believe it’s actually quite the contrary. It is a strength to be able to make values-based decisions amid feeling fear and anxiety. It is a strength to feel fear and discomfort and tolerate that experience. It is a strength to get up each day knowing there is a battle ahead (or present). Feeling fear is not a sign of weakness but rather a sign of humanness.
.
.
Humans (including yourself) will experience a myriad of emotional experiences. This includes fear, anxiety, discomfort, etc. I believe in your ability to redefine your definition of strength (if it needs it). I believe in your ability to validate your strength in living each day fighting against fear and anxiety making your choices. I believe in your ability to do hard things. I believe in YOU! You got this💪
.
.

This is for anyone who needs this reminder today. You can do hard things even when your anxiety, depression, eating disorder, self-critic, self-doubt, perfectionism, etc. is screaming at you that you can’t. You can do hard things even when you don’t want to do them. You can do hard things even when your stomach is churning and your body wants you to escape. You can do hard things even when you don’t feel like you can. You can do hard things. I believe in your ability to do hard things. I believe in YOU!
.
.

Choosing values over fear is not always an easy choice. Sometimes (oftentimes?) it will be “easier" to make a decision based on fear rather than your values. This leads to an immediate feeling of relief; however, that relief is temporary. It also might be coupled with regret, sadness, and demoralization. That fear-based avoidance actually reinforces the scary stimuli leading to a stronger fear association.
.
.
To choose values over fear is such a strength. You may tremble the whole time. You may feel fear coursing through your veins. Part of you may wish you hadn’t said “bring it on” to your anxiety. The situation might not play out the way you had hoped it would, but there is such tremendous benefit to making decisions based on values. This is your life to live; not fear’s.
.
.
I believe in your ability to do hard things. I believe in your ability to do scary things. I believe in your ability to walk towards your fear and resist retreating. I believe in you SO much! You got this💪
.
.

What would you do differently if you fully believed in yourself and what you were going for?

Me: “Alexa, what am I supposed to be doing with my life?” Alexa: “Hmm, I don’t know that”
.
Just a general rule of thumb...if Alexa doesn’t know, you’re off the hook! Haha!🤷🏼‍♀️
.
Where are you going to college? What will you study? What are you going to do after you graduate? When are you getting married? Are you going to have any children? Are you just going to be a stay at home mom/dad (said in a condescending tone)? on and on until forever...
.
Repeat after me: “I DON’T KNOW,” end of sentence. I know, it feels so weird...because not knowing means we’re incompetent and unprepared, am I right? Plot twist: we’re all pretty unprepared for life, so why are we trying to play it off like we’ve got it all together?
.
“I don’t know:” perfectly good enough answer! Use it, lean in to it, and bask in the glory of making choices whenever YOU want to, not when you’re “supposed” to.
.
Do you ever feel the pressure to have all the answers? Can I get a 🙋‍♀️
.
.
.
❤️Reposted @holisticallygrace

I’m sad that the day came where this post was ever necessary and to try and avoid any controversy I am going to put a TW on this post: 
Last night everything got too much. Something clicked and after a long time of fighting every suicidal thought or urge I had, I just couldn’t fight it anymore. I took an overdose last night. The world was not on my side and everything got too much for me. The good news is is that I’m safe, I’m home and hopefully the mental health team I’ve been discharged to will actually start to do something. However, and let this be a lesson to you all, I massively regret my decision to do something of the sort - I was overwhelmed and quite honestly done fighting with all my might everyday. Yes this is a huge setback and yes an all time low but I’m trying to turn it around and find the positives in what was a horrific experience. I’m safe, I’m at home (which I’m grateful for as there was potential of being put on a psych ward), I’m going to start (hopefully) getting the help I need, I’m confident that next time I will speak to my parents before I get to this point and I’m hoping it will be the start of turning my life around for the better. I’m sorry if I’ve let anyone down or disappointed anyone, life just got too much for me but please know that I’m in a more positive mindset this morning and I feel ready to start fighting once again and beat these stupid illnesses! I can do this. I want to thank my incredible (understatement) friends who were there for me last night - I don’t know what I would do without you. Anyway I’m safe and that’s what matters. Keep fighting everyone and if anyone has any questions just drop me a message and I’ll try my best to answer honestly. Lots of love to you all and keep fighting ~ Abbi xxx #depression #ocd #stopthestigma

A lot of the time I can’t find the right words to describe depression. It’s exhausting it’s draining it’s upsetting. It feels like the life is being sucked out of you and the small amount of energy you have takes all your effort to use. I’m sad to say that a lot of my smiles are forced at the moment - and when you’re depressed it really does take all your effort to smile. A lot of the time it feels like the world is crumbling around you and even getting out of bed in the morning is a task that pretty much hoovers up all your energy. Depression is real and depression sucks! BUT: things will get better, there will be happy times and you will continue to make amazing memories. Use the people around you as motivation to get better and live a happier life. Don’t let depression win all the time (sometimes is fine) but not all the time. Please read: if someone were to see me looking like this I.e. in my pjs in the mid afternoon with a blanket wrapped around myself, they would probably ask if I was unwell. With the absence of a cold or the flu or anything of the sort I would probably automatically answer ‘no’. But in reality the answer is yes. Yes I am unwell! Just not physically. Today my depression is getting the better of me, my mental illness is dominating so yes I am unwell/not feeling very well/ill. But I would never openly answer yes to that question in reference to my mental health. It’s a difficult one because answering yes to that question opens up a whole new conversation with the person asking the question but it would be the truth. Mental illness is still an illness and I think, although resilience and fight is obviously needed, we should still treat it like it’s an illness simply because that’s what it is. I don’t know - what are everyone else’s thoughts? Hope you’re all ok and keep fighting everyone😁😁 #ocd #stopthestigma

Jumping to assumptions is much easier than collecting facts. In a world of information overload and many different opinions it can be easy to get caught up should we lose our ability to think, and instead unconsciously accept. The fear of giving up worry matches the fear of living free, but this is all a program that can be re-evaluated. Instead of looking for the right day, the right feeling, or the right person to begin your healing look for the right perception within. You’re stronger and wiser than you give yourself credit for. You are more than anxiety, and anxiety has no place in your future identity. .
Stay Inspired, Stay Informed, Follow Along. ❤️

Do you want to know what the greatest roadblock is for a health anxiety sufferer on their road to freedom? I call it the standing guard cycle. This cycle presupposes that if a health anxiety sufferer stands guard at the doorway of their body throughout each and every moment of their life, and reacts instinctively and fearfully to anything that may seem ‘abnormal’ to them in their body, they stay in the safe zone. The safe zone is to be able to maintain this run of survival they have going, to hope for change but to run the same mental, emotional habits from day to day due to the formula that safety lies within worry, and safety lies within what’s been familiar.
.
Standing guard means to tense up the body, this is something the health anxiety sufferer doesn’t recognize though because they are solely concerned about the impulsive reaction to what they view as an abnormal feeling in the body. By standing guard though we tense up the body and internal organs causing an even greater amount of misinterpretations to any external stimuli that shows up. A tense body picks up on other peoples language that may touch on the topic of illness instantly. A tense body will become 100 times more stimulated to sound, smell, and taste.
.
Standing guard keeps the anxious identity in tact, in fact strengthening it by the day. The longer a paradigm, or a set of habits have been in place, the more difficult it becomes to break. Why would your system begin seeing the sensations and the world in a whole different light? It kept you alive up to now didn’t it? It did, but it sucks to live by standing guard constantly. If the subconscious mind/body wants to stand guard, that fine, that’s it’s job anyway which is to keep you safe and to keep you happy. But the conscious mind doesn’t have to join in. The conscious mind upon recognIzing a lengthy period of standing guard can break free through the power of mindfulness and begin partaking in a new viewpoint over the sensation it feels. #MoreThanAnxiety
.
